title: Today on the Hill : The latest developments on Capitol Hill
body_text:
WTOP Capitol Hill Correspondent Mitchell Miller follows all the developments in Congress. To keep up with the latest, visit the Today on the Hill webpage.
Former Proud Boys leader Enrique Tarrio arrested on assault charge after return to US Capitol
Members of the Proud Boys, the right-wing group that was a key part of the mob that broke into the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, to try to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election, returned on Friday to Capitol grounds.
After holding a news conference, former Proud Boys leader Enrique Tarrio was arrested by U.S. Capitol Police, following a brief confrontation with a counterprotester.
Officers said they saw Tarrio hit the woman’s cellphone and her arm after the woman put the phone near his face.
She told police she wanted to make a complaint, and Tarrio was charged with simple assault.
Read the full story here.
Lawmakers concerned about DOGE dive into IRS, taxpayer information, aviation system
President Donald Trump has only been back in the White House for a month, but with billionaire Elon Musk leading the way, his administration has already fired more than 10,000 federal employees — and the number is only growing.
The IRS is among the latest agencies targeted by Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE).
House Speaker Johnson won't 'second-guess' Trump Jan. 6 pardons
House Speaker Mike Johnson said Wednesday he would not second-guess President Donald Trump’s decision to pardon or commute the sentences of violent offenders who attacked the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and called former President Joe Biden’s pardons of his family members “disgusting.”
Johnson had not spoken extensively about Trump’s pardons, which were announced on Monday when he signed an executive order covering close to 1,500 people.
US Supreme Court upholds ban on TikTok
The Supreme Court on Friday upheld a federal ban on TikTok, which is set to go into effect Sunday, unless it is sold by its Chinese parent company.
There was no dissent among the high court justices.
The ban was approved by Congress and signed into law by President Joe Biden amid national security concerns linked to TikTok’s Chinese ownership.
Trump, GOP lawmakers have ambitious agenda for first 100 days
Donald Trump will be sworn in as president at his inauguration on Jan. 20, and with GOP control of the House and Senate, Republicans are eager to begin a sprint toward enacting his legislative agenda.
Read the full story here.
US Capitol ready for Jan. 6 election certification
Four years after his supporters broke into the U.S. Capitol to try to overturn the 2020 election results, Congress plans Monday to certify that Donald Trump won the latest presidential election.
The Jan. 6 joint session of Congress, until 2021, had always been a largely ceremonial event to count the Electoral College votes.
This year, it is a National Special Security Event, which greatly enhances law enforcement surrounding the U.S. Capitol.
Read the full story here.
Congress gives final approval averting a government shutdown after midnight deadline
The Senate gave the final approval for a short-term spending bill on Friday night, over half a hour past its midnight deadline, averting a government shutdown ahead of the holidays.
The Senate vote was 85-11, and came after the House easily approved the legislation, after days of political drama that included President-elect Donald Trump and Elon Musk making last-minute demands to House Speaker Mike Johnson.
The continuing resolution, which extends spending until March 14, now goes to President Joe Biden for his signature.
In addition to keeping the government up and running, the measure includes $100 billion in federal disaster relief and $10 billion in aid to farmers, with an extension of the Farm Bill.
The legislation includes full federal funding for rebuilding the Key Bridge in Baltimore, Maryland, which collapsed earlier this year after being struck by a large container ship.
President Joe Biden signed the continuing resolution into law just before 11:30 a.m. on Saturday, staving off a government shutdown.
Surprising late-night passage of RFK bill
Language which would have given D.C. control of the former RFK stadium site was stripped from the bill ahead of passage Friday, dealing the District a blow to its effort to redevelop the area with a new stadium and bring the Washington Commanders back to the city.
“While I am disappointed that the House-passed version of the CR did not contain the bill, which I’ve worked on since 2017, I am hopeful that D.C. will eventually get control of the land and transform it from crumbling blight to a productive and bustling complex that will generate significant revenue for the nation’s capital,” D.C. Del. Eleanor Holmes Norton said in a statement.
However, in the early hours of Saturday morning, D.C. netted a surprising legislative Hail Mary in the U.S. Senate as it approved an RFK bill by unanimous consent.
The measure was introduced on the Senate floor by Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-Ny.) as a standalone item, not as part of the continuing resolution aimed at keeping the government open. It was able to reach the floor of the Senate thanks to House passage of the RFK revitalization bill in late February.
Without any objection from other senators — including those representing Prince George’s County, Maryland, where the Commanders currently play — the bill all but cements District control of the RFK site.
Statement from MD Senators Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen on transfer of control involving RFK stadium site to D.C:
“We have always supported the District’s effort to control its own land and….our concerns with this proposal have been addressed.” They did not block bill.— Mitchell Miller (@mmillerwtop) December 21, 2024
“We are extremely grateful that our elected officials have come together on a bipartisan basis to give Washington D.C. the opportunity to decide on the future of the RFK stadium site. This bill will create an equal playing field so that all potential future locations for the home of the Washington Commanders can be fairly considered and give our franchise the opportunity to provide the best experience for all of our fans,” Washington Commanders managing partner Josh Harris said in a statement Saturday morning.
Sens. Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen had previously been among the elected leaders who opposed the effort, calling keeping the Commanders in Maryland their “first priority.” Saturday morning they explained why they didn’t choose to oppose the bill when it was brought on the Senate floor early Saturday morning.
“Maryland has been the proud home of the Commanders for over two decades and we continue to believe that this partnership should continue long into the future,” Sens. Cardin and Van Hollen said in a joint statement. “After working to level the financial playing field, and receiving assurances that should the team move they will redevelop the existing site in a manner that meets the needs of the community, tonight we supported the proposed land transfer legislation. We have always supported the District’s effort to control its own land, and through regional discussions and cooperation, our concerns with this proposal have been addressed.”
House approves GOP bill that would avert government shutdown
The House has approved a new short-term spending plan that would avert a government shutdown, sending the legislation on to the Senate.
The vote was 366-34, with one voting present. Thirty-four Republicans voted against the GOP-led bill.
The continuing resolution would extend federal spending to March 14 and includes federal disaster aid, as well as assistance for farmers. The vote comes after two major setbacks for House Speaker Mike Johnson, whose first proposal was torpedoed by President-elect Donald Trump and his ally Elon Musk.
A second bill, which included an extension of the debt limit for two years that had been sought by Trump, was soundly defeated.
Rep. Rosa DeLauro, D-CT, the ranking Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee, criticized Republicans as well as Musk before the vote.
“American policy should be set on behalf of America’s workers. Not billionaires, who cozy up to communist China,” DeLauro said, referring to Musk as she urged lawmakers to take up the original legislation Johnson proposed with Democratic support.
But Rep. Dan Meuser, R-PA, praised Musk’s involvement, saying his social media postings helped with “streamlining bloated legislation and exposing it to the American people, which resulted in a better, leaner deal.”
Musk’s critics pointed out that he reposted erroneous information, including a claim that a $3 billion stadium for D.C. was included in the original legislation. In truth, that bill only included language stating that D.C. could take control of the RFK stadium site, which could help with efforts to return the Commanders to the District.
The D.C. language related to the RFK site was not included in the bill the House passed on Friday. Instead, thanks in part to passage of a House bill earlier this year, the Senate was able to act on this measure outside of a continuing resolution.
The legislation does, however, include federal funding to replace the Key Bridge in Baltimore, which collapsed earlier this year after being hit by a container ship.
House sets up vote to prevent government shutdown, dropping Trump’s demand for debt limit
Veering toward a midnight Friday government shutdown, House Speaker Mike Johnson proposed a new plan that would temporarily fund federal operations and disaster aid, but punted President-elect Donald Trump demands for a debt limit increase into the new year.
House Republicans have been meeting behind closed doors on next steps after Trump doubled down on his insistence that a debt ceiling increase be included in any deal — and if not, he said in an early morning post, let the closures “start now.”
“We will not have a government shutdown,” Johnson said as he left the basement session at the Capitol.
Johnson set a vote for Friday evening, but the outcome was uncertain. He declined to disclose the new idea under consideration but lawmakers said it would fund the government at current levels through March and adds $100 billion in disaster aid and $10 billion in agricultural assistance to farmers.
Read the full story from The Associated Press.
Republicans meet to consider newest plan to avert shutdown
House Republicans have completed a meeting behind closed doors about the latest proposal to avoid a government shutdown.
House Majority Leader Steve Scalise says they are still considering on how to proceed with votes on separate parts of the new plan.
“We’re looking at the different options to keep the government running, to provide disaster relief and to help our farmers,” Scalise told reporters as he came out of a meeting in the basement of the U.S. Capitol.
He says the discussions involve whether to try to pass the legislation through a rule, or suspension of the rules.
That’s a big distinction, since if it is passed through the House Rules Committee, the legislation only needs a simple majority.
But if legislation comes up through suspension of the rules, it requires a two-thirds majority — which means Republicans would need Democrats to help with passage.
That did not happen with a vote on Thursday night, when nearly all of Democrats voted against Johnson’s second proposal.
House Speaker has new last-ditch plan to avoid government shutdown
House Speaker Mike Johnson has come up with Plan C, as lawmakers scramble to try to avert a government shutdown before a Friday midnight deadline.
The latest plan, coming after two stinging setbacks for Johnson, reportedly calls for breaking up the legislation that’s been so difficult to pass.
One part could be a continuing resolution to fund the government through March 14 and avert a shutdown.
A second part would provide for federal disaster aid for states hit hard by recent hurricanes. And a third part would go toward farm assistance.
Republicans were meeting Friday afternoon to go over the proposal, which follows a decisive defeat Thursday night for a measure that included an extension of the debt limit for two years — something President-elect Donald Trump sought.
Even though Trump backed that plan, 38 Republicans voted against it.
The latest proposal does not include lifting the debt limit, which would be left to be addressed by the 119th Congress in the coming year, when Republicans control the White House, U.S. House and U.S. Senate.
House Democrats have been meeting as well, as they consider how to deal with the latest GOP proposal.
Virtually all Democrats voted against the legislation that came up on the floor Thursday night.
“Republicans are marching America to a painful government shutdown,” House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries said as he headed into the meeting with Democrats on Thursday morning.
Details of when votes will be scheduled are still being discussed.
New legislation seeks to protect federal workers from winds of political change
Democratic U.S. senators from Virginia and Maryland sought unsuccessfully to pass new legislation Tuesday that would protect federal civil servants from being unfairly terminated by a new president.
The “Saving the Civil Service Act,” sponsored by Virginia Sen. Tim Kaine, would prevent any position in the federal civil service from being reclassified outside of merit system principles without the consent of Congress.
It comes as a response to President-elect Donald Trump’s plan to bring back “Schedule F,” which would make it easier to reclassify and fire federal workers.
Maryland Sen. Ben Cardin said it would be “outrageous” for federal workers to, effectively, be forced to take a political test to keep their jobs.
“We’ve got to stop that. And this is a real threat,” Cardin said.
Read the full story here.
Congress races to avoid government shutdown before the holidays
Congressional leaders are racing to finish up this session’s legislative work, including a short-term spending bill that will need to be approved this week to avoid a government shutdown right before the holidays.
The continuing resolution is expected to be agreed upon soon and must be approved by the House and Senate by Friday at midnight.
It’s likely to include tens of billions of dollars in federal disaster aid to help states ravaged in recent months by hurricanes Helene and Milton, as well as severe storms.
Town Hall seeks to help federal workers worried about losing their jobs
Federal workers across the D.C. area are bracing for possible cuts to the government workforce that President-elect Donald Trump has pledged to implement when he returns to the White House.
Rep. Glenn Ivey, D-Md., said that’s why he put together the Tele-Town Hall on Thursday evening, which allowed federal workers and people concerned about major cuts to federal agencies to dial in.
“I think it’s tragic,” Ivey said. “We’ve got a lot of federal employees who’ve been doing great work here for the country for many, many years. And I think they’re vilified and targeted in this way.”
Ivey said he and other members of the Maryland congressional delegation are trying to help protect federal jobs.
Trump has said he plans to reimplement Schedule F, which effectively could make it easier to fire federal employees without cause.
Big drop in workers coming into DC offices could lead to economic ‘headwinds’
D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser told Congress on Tuesday that the District is doing well across the board, with economic improvements, a drop in crime and a growing population.
“I say, without equivocation, the state of the nation’s capital is strong,” Bowser said in testimony before a House Appropriations subcommittee.
But there is still concern about a huge drop since the pandemic in the number of federal workers coming into offices in D.C.
Glen Lee, the city’s chief financial officer, told lawmakers D.C. faces economic “headwinds” linked to remote work.
Incoming Congress will have record number of Black lawmakers
The 119th Congress that will be sworn in next year will have a record number of Black lawmakers, including Angela Alsobrooks, the first Black woman to be elected a U.S. Senator from Maryland.
There will also be an unprecedented number of Democrats in the Congressional Black Caucus — 62 in total. In addition, there will also be five Black Republican lawmakers.
The total of 67 Black lawmakers will be the most ever in Congress and builds on the growth of recent years. Fifty years ago, in 1974, there were only 17 Black members in Congress.
Read the rest of the story here.
House speaker says US Capitol women's bathrooms off-limits to transgender lawmaker
House Speaker Mike Johnson said Wednesday that women’s bathrooms in the U.S. Capitol complex will be restricted to biological women — meaning the first transgender person elected to Congress won’t be allowed in them.
Johnson issued a statement after Rep. Nancy Mace, R-South Carolina filed a resolution this week that would prohibit any lawmakers from “using single-sex facilities other than those corresponding to their biological sex.”
Her proposal was in direct response to the election of Democrat Sarah McBride of Delaware, who is the first openly transgender person elected to Congress. She will be sworn in next year.
“All single-sex facilities in the Capitol and House Office Buildings — such as restrooms, changing rooms and locker rooms — are reserved for individuals of that biological sex,” Johnson said in his statement.
“It is important to note that each member office has its own private restroom, and unisex restrooms are available throughout the Capitol,” he added.
McBride earlier criticized Mace’s proposal.
“This is a blatant attempt from far right-wing extremists to distract from the fact that they have no real solutions to what Americans are facing,” McBride said.
One of the bathrooms on the House side of the Capitol has a sign on its wooden doors that has been up for years.
It says, “Men Only.”
Johnson on Tuesday made his personal position clear.
“A man is a man, and a woman is a woman, and a man cannot become a woman,” he said.
He added that everyone should be treated “with dignity.”
Should federal workers worry about Elon Musk eliminating their jobs?
President-elect Donald Trump’s new Department of Government Efficiency pledges to “send shockwaves” through the U.S. government and eliminate massive waste as well as the jobs of federal workers.
The department — which is not actually part of the government — is being led by Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy, two entrepreneurs who share Trump’s view that the federal bureaucracy must be slashed.
Trump said the commission will provide recommendations and work with the White House “to dismantle government bureaucracy, slash excess regulations, cut wasteful expenditures and restructure federal agencies.”
Musk has suggested that DOGE (a nod to cryptocurrency Dogecoin) will seek to cut as much as $2 trillion in federal spending.
“This will send shockwaves through the system, and anyone involved in government waste, which is a lot of people!” Musk said in a statement.
Republicans could control White House, Senate and House
Former President Donald Trump — now the president-elect — has just completed one of the most extraordinary political comebacks in U.S. history.
Not only has he defeated Vice President Kamala Harris in the Electoral College count, but he appears to be on track to become the first Republican presidential candidate to win the popular vote since 2004.
Less than four years ago, his political future appeared to be near an end, after his supporters broke into the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, in an effort to overturn the 2020 presidential election.
He was impeached — for a second time.
He was criticized by Republican congressional leaders in the wake of the attack.
Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham, of South Carolina, said, “Count me out,” during a speech on the Senate floor, suggesting he was cutting ties with the president.
But only a month later, Graham was in Florida, playing golf with Trump as the former president worked on his political rehabilitation.
Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, who has privately criticized Trump, congratulated him on his victory and was glowing at a news conference Wednesday.
“It’s certainly a happy day for the GOP,” he said, smiling.
McConnell will remain in the Senate, but is stepping away from his leadership role.
McConnell said he’s glad to hand off to a Republican who will become the Senate Majority Leader.
“I’ve been the majority leader, I’ve been the minority leader — majority’s a lot better,” he said wryly.
GOP Senate majority
Trump will have a Senate majority that will be larger than the 51-49 edge that Democrats had before the election.
At least 52 Republicans will be represented in the upper chamber and the number may rise, depending on what happens in close races in Pennsylvania and Nevada.
The House may also retain its GOP majority, though numerous races still need to be decided.
As of Wednesday, Republicans had a lead of more than a dozen seats.
If all House seats are filled, 218 is the number required for a majority.
In Virginia, neither party flipped a seat in House races.
Democrat Eugene Vindman is leading in the 7th District race against Republican Derrick Anderson to replace Rep. Abigail Spanberger, who is stepping down to run for governor.
In the 2nd District, it appears Republican Rep. Jen Kiggans will hold off a tough challenge from Democrat Missy Cotter Smasal.
But many races have yet to be called, including several in California.
It could take days for the winners of those contests to be announced.
If the House is held by the GOP, Trump will have a political trifecta — the White House, House and Senate.
There is also a conservative majority on the U.S. Supreme Court, which includes three justices nominated by Trump.
Virginia senator calls for election vigilance
Virginia U.S. Sen. Mark Warner, the chair of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said that he’s concerned the final days before the election will bring a surge of disinformation designed to confuse and anger voters.
He said voters need to be vigilant and vet what they see on social media.
“It’s going to be a tense time,” Warner said. “Please don’t jump to conclusions.”
The Democratic lawmaker, who is not up for reelection, said Russia, China and Iran have shown time and again that they want to meddle in U.S. elections.
Presidential candidates make closing arguments ahead of Election Day

The tumultuous presidential campaign between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump will finally wind down in exactly one week — on Nov. 5.
Harris is making her “closing argument” Tuesday evening on the Ellipse near the White House, where Trump spoke to supporters on Jan. 6, 2021, shortly before they rioted at the U.S. Capitol and tried to overturn the 2020 election results.
Trump held a rally Sunday night in New York at Madison Square Garden, where he outlined the dangers of illegal immigration and “the enemy within,” which he’s spoken about frequently in the waning days of the campaign.
His speech was overshadowed by media coverage of various controversial comments made by others who spoke during the event.
Many Republicans in Congress have urged the former president to focus on the economy, as well as the border.
But Trump appears to be convinced that the border will be the animating issue that drives his supporters to the polls.
Harris, meanwhile, hopes to draw a sharp contrast with Trump by speaking where he did on Jan. 6.
Her campaign initially backed away from President Joe Biden’s heated rhetoric about Trump being a threat to democracy.
But Harris has turned up the rhetoric, in the wake of comments from Trump’s former chief of staff, John Kelly, who said in an interview with the New York Times he believes his former boss wants to rule like a dictator.
It remains to be seen whether various developments in the homestretch of the campaign will make a difference in the election, especially since tens of millions of people have already voted.
The final battle for the battleground states
The election is widely expected to come down to turnout in the seven battleground states, where polls indicate Harris and Trump remain extremely close.
Pennsylvania, and its 19 electoral votes, remains the top political prize.
Harris campaigned in Pennsylvania on Sunday and Trump is scheduled to campaign in the Keystone State on Tuesday.
Harris was in Michigan on Monday, and after her address in D.C., is scheduled to campaign again in Pennsylvania on Wednesday, along with Wisconsin and North Carolina.
She has also planned campaign stops this week in Arizona and Nevada.
Trump was in Georgia on Monday. After Pennsylvania, he’ll hold a rally Wednesday in Wisconsin, then visit Nevada on Thursday and return to Wisconsin on Friday.
He also plans to campaign in Virginia on Saturday, though it’s not considered to be one of the battleground states.
Republicans hold edge in effort to retake US Senate
Democrats always knew they faced a difficult political map to retain their narrow majority in the U.S. Senate this election year.
Maryland’s U.S. Senate seat opened up with the retirement of longtime Democratic Sen. Ben Cardin, but it was initially not considered in play, since voters hadn’t elected a Republican senator in more than four decades.
But that changed when former Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan became the GOP nominee in the race against Prince George’s County Executive Angela Alsobrooks.
Battle for control of US House is as close as White House race
Control of the U.S. House of Representatives could turn on just a handful of competitive congressional races across the country.
All 435 seats are up for reelection, but political analysts said it will all boil down to roughly two dozen contests.
Republicans have held one of the narrowest vote margins in the history of the lower chamber, which has contributed to legislative dysfunction. The GOP currently holds 220 seats, while Democrats have 212 seats — three seats are unfilled.
National presidential race goes regional

Americans across the country will go to the polls two weeks from now, but millions have already voted, and the presidential candidates will be focused on just a handful of states.
The campaigning strategy this week reflects the Electoral College reality: the 2024 presidential election will likely be decided by voters in the seven battleground states.
Vice President Kamala Harris campaigned Monday in suburbs of Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin — three states that could be critical to getting her to the necessary 270 electoral votes to get elected.
She campaigned in Philadelphia with former Wyoming Rep. Liz Cheney, who was once part of the Republican U.S. House leadership but became GOP persona non grata after repeatedly criticizing former President Donald Trump in the wake of the Jan. 6 insurrection.
Trump went to another battleground state, North Carolina, where he praised the work of people who have helped victims of Hurricane Helene.
But he again criticized the Federal Emergency Management Agency, repeating a baseless claim that the agency diverted disaster assistance to people in the country illegally.
Trump, who has been critical of early and mail-in voting in the past, also praised the early voting efforts in North Carolina, a state he will likely need to win to return to the White House.
Democrats have not won the Tar Heel State since former President Barack Obama narrowly did so in 2008.
Who are the ‘deciders’ in this election?
The latest polls continue to suggest that voters are nearly equally divided in the seven battlegrounds states of Michigan, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, North Carolina, Georgia, Arizona and Nevada.
Harris and Trump are within the margin of error in all of those states.
A new Washington Post-Schar School poll tried to dig deeper, by examining voters who haven’t made up their minds and could ultimately be the “deciders” in a very close race.
The poll suggests that younger voters will be a wild card, 43% between the ages of 18 and 25 said they are uncommitted.
Among registered voters in the seven states, 37% said they will “definitely” vote for Harris and 37% will “definitely” back Trump — or they’ve already voted for each of the candidates.
The Post reported the “definite” support for Harris is a significant increase from a survey in the spring, when 26% said they would definitely vote for President Joe Biden.
Trump’s support rose from 31% to 37%.
But only 13% of “probably Harris” voters said they would be enthusiastic if she wins, with 11% of “probably Trump” voters saying the same about him returning to the White House.
The overall margin of error for the poll is plus-or-minus 1.7%.
For the states, it is between plus-or-minus 3.9 and 5%.
Three weeks to Election Day, who's winning?

While there have been all kinds of developments during the presidential campaign, one aspect of the race between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump has remained constant: tight polling.
A new NBC News poll of registered voters out this week has the two candidates deadlocked at 48% each.
The poll suggests Harris has lost some ground since she entered the race during the summer, after President Joe Biden withdrew.
An NBC News poll in September had Harris leading Trump 49% to 44%.
The latest poll has a margin of error of plus-or-minus 3.1%.
In polls conducted in battleground states, the two candidates remain neck and neck.
Both Harris and Trump campaigned again Monday in Pennsylvania, which could be the state that determines who wins the presidential election.
The latest CBS News poll of likely voters in Pennsylvania has the candidates tied at 49% each.
They are also tied in Wisconsin at 49% and Harris has a slight lead of 50% to 48% in Michigan.
Trump leads 50% to 49% in Arizona, Georgia and North Carolina, while the poll has Harris with a slight lead of 50% to 48% in Nevada.
The CBS News poll has Harris ahead of Trump nationally, 51% to 48%.
The national poll has a margin of error of plus-or-minus 2.3%.
The findings from the survey also illustrate how differently Democrats and Republicans view the federal response to damage from recent hurricanes.
The survey found 83% of Republicans believe Trump’s claims that the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s hurricane funds are being diverted to people in the U.S. illegally, while 90% of Democrats believe that’s false.
FEMA has said the claim is untrue.
Harris to appear on Fox
Harris has recently stepped up her interviews and she’s about to do something Biden hasn’t done since becoming president — sit down for an interview on Fox News.
The network announced that Harris will be interviewed by Fox News chief political anchor Brett Baier and the interview will air at 6 p.m. on Wednesday.
The interview will take place on a network that often criticizes Harris and presents a flood of stories that are generally more favorable to Trump.
But it also represents a chance for Harris to show she’s not afraid to go into enemy political territory and possibly attract some independent voters.
Harris’ running mate, Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, has recently been interviewed twice on “Fox News Sunday.”
In an effort to reach out to female voters, Trump plans to take part in a Fox town hall in which the audience will all be women. The town hall is set to air the same day that Harris does her interview on Fox.
Harris this week is also doing interviews designed to shore up her support among Black voters.
While being interviewed by Roland Martin on Monday, Harris suggested that Trump has a history of racist behavior.
Harris also recorded an interview on Tuesday in Detroit with Charlamagne tha God for his syndicated morning radio show, “The Breakfast Club.”
How is the US Postal Service dealing with mail-in ballots?
Concerns have been raised in Congress that the U.S. Postal Service might not be up to the task of providing timely delivery of mail-in ballots, but Virginia lawmakers say they were reassured after a recent meeting with the U.S. Postmaster General.
Mail-in ballots have grown in popularity, especially in the wake of the pandemic.
Virginia’s congressional delegation has been keeping a close eye on the handling of mail-in ballots, in part because of past problems with deliveries and lost mail in the commonwealth.
U.S. Senators Mark Warner and Tim Kaine, along with Rep. Abigail Spanberger, D-7th, and Rep. Jennifer McClellan, D-4th, met on Friday with Postmaster General Louis DeJoy in Richmond. A representative from the office of Rep. Rob Wittman, R-1st, also took part in the meeting.
Spanberger said the lawmakers wanted DeJoy “to make sure that the agency is working to deliver a higher standard of service ahead of Election Day to make sure ballots arrive on time.”
She and the other lawmakers said they were encouraged by what they heard from DeJoy about stepped up training and other reforms aimed at getting mail delivered in a timely manner.
Spanberger said on average, it takes 2.18 days for a ballot to either be sent to a voter, or for a voter to send a ballot back to election officials.
In September, the Virginia Commissioner of Elections, Susan Beals, told a state panel that she had concerns that mail-in ballots might not be processed in time.
Several secretaries of state also testified before Congress about issues they worried about involving the mail, including threats made against election workers.
Warner said after the meeting on Friday that he believes there has been “dramatic improvement” in mail delivery, which has come under particular scrutiny in the Richmond area.
Absentee and early voting began on Sept. 20 in Virginia.
The deadline to apply for an absentee mail-in ballot is Oct. 25, though it is recommended people make their request earlier.
Hurricane season whips up political rhetoric, misinformation

Hurricane Milton quickly intensified to Category 5 strength Monday and former President Donald Trump has intensified attacks on Vice President Kamala Harris in the past week, making several baseless claims related to the response to Hurricane Helene.
The battleground state of North Carolina is still trying to address the devastation from widespread flooding linked to Helene.
Trump has sought to portray the Biden-Harris administration’s federal response as a disaster.
“They stole the FEMA money just like they stole it from a bank, so they could give it to their illegal immigrants that they want to have vote for them,” Trump said at a rally last week in Michigan.
The accusation is entirely untrue and has been criticized by the White House.
No money has been taken from FEMA for migrants, at the expense of disaster victims. Earlier this year, Congress approved $650 million for a separate matter, called the Shelters and Services Grant Program, which assists migrants and tries to help communities deal with them when they come across the border.
Trump has made several other unfounded claims, including that the Biden administration was preventing assistance from getting to heavily Republican areas.
There has been so much misinformation from various sources that FEMA has a link on its website dedicated to knocking down rumors and baseless claims made on social media.
White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Monday some of the misinformation was “dangerous” because it can discourage people from applying for assistance, in the incorrect belief that programs have run out of money or won’t provide help for various reasons.
“Hurricane politics” will likely continue for some time, especially with Milton expected to make landfall in Florida later this week.
Mini-media blitz from VP Harris
Harris has come under attack from Republicans for not making herself available for media interviews and unscripted events.
She is now in the midst of a series of interviews from a wide range of sources.
An interview with CBS’ “60 Minutes” aired on Monday night, in which she addressed a wide range of major issues, including the U.S. relationship with Israel.
She is also doing a series of interviews designed to address younger voters and women.
